title: 106_hr942
content: The "Broadcast Ownership for the 21st Century Act" amends the Communications Act of 1934 by adding a new section that revises duopoly rules. The Broadcast Ownership for the 21st Century Act amends duopoly rules by allowing ownership of two stations with overlapping coverage contours in separate television markets or two television stations within the same market if one is a UHF station. Existing local marketing agreements between stations in the same market are protected and exempt from the duopoly rule. The Broadcast Ownership for the 21st Century Act allows ownership of two stations in separate television markets or two television stations in the same market under certain conditions. The Commission may permit ownership of two VHF television stations in the same market if it does not harm competition or media diversity. SEC. 3. CROSS-OWNERSHIP LIMITATIONS. The Federal Communications Commission will modify regulations to eliminate restrictions on granting broadcast station licenses based on ownership of a daily newspaper and remove the one-to-a-market rule. Minority voting stock interests will not be considered a cognizable interest if one holder owns over 50% of the voting stock. The Federal Communications Commission will revise regulations to allow ownership of a broadcasting station and a cable system in the same community. Additionally, dual-network rules will be revised to permit television broadcast stations to affiliate with entities maintaining multiple networks. The Federal Communications Commission will revise regulations to allow ownership of a broadcasting station and a cable system in the same community. This includes permitting television broadcast stations to affiliate with entities maintaining multiple networks. The deadline for these modifications is 90 days after the enactment of the Act. The Telecommunications Act of 1996 is amended to increase the ownership limit from 35% to 45%. The Federal Communications Commission must implement this change within 90 days. Additionally, reciprocal treatment of foreign ownership restrictions is addressed. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to restrict foreign ownership in broadcast and common carrier licenses. No licenses shall be granted to aliens, foreign corporations, or corporations with significant foreign ownership. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to restrict foreign ownership in broadcast and common carrier licenses. Licenses will not be granted to corporations with significant foreign ownership if it is deemed against the public interest. Foreign countries that allow broadcast station licenses to be held by foreigners may receive reciprocal treatment. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to restrict foreign ownership in broadcast and common carrier licenses. Licenses will not be granted to corporations with significant foreign ownership if it is deemed against the public interest. The Commission may allow foreign entities to own a portion of the capital stock of a corporation holding a broadcast station license, based on the ownership rules in the foreign country. Licenses will not be granted to corporations with significant foreign ownership if it is deemed against the public interest. The Commission may allow foreign entities to own a portion of the capital stock of a corporation holding a broadcast station license in a foreign country, with a voting stock limit of 40 percent for United States persons. Licenses will not be granted to corporations with significant foreign ownership if it is against the public interest.
